title: Policy Applications (Restricted Distribution)
text:
My research develops quantitative tools that can support economic intelligence and policy analysis in environments characterized by strategic interaction, uncertainty, and systemic interdependence.


I study how production networks transmit shocks arising from trade restrictions, sanctions, and input shortages. The models identify critical nodes and substitution margins that determine whether disruptions are absorbed through reallocation or amplified into persistent vulnerabilities. This framework can inform assessments of supply-chain robustness and exposure to foreign dependencies.



My work on energy substitution and capital adjustment characterizes how economies respond over time to energy price shocks, carbon pricing, and technology constraints. These dynamics are directly relevant for evaluating energy dependence, transition risks, and the strategic implications of supply disruptions.



By embedding policy frictions in dynamic general equilibrium models, I examine how small, persistent distortions generate nonlinear aggregate responses. The approach is suited to identifying early-stage vulnerabilities that may not be apparent in reduced-form or sector-level analyses.



Across projects, I focus on how policy instruments interact with private investment incentives. This perspective is relevant for evaluating the unintended consequences of industrial policy, sanctions, and regulatory interventions in adversarial or competitive environments.
This work is intended to complement qualitative intelligence assessments with formal, mechanism-based economic analysis.

Taylor-McGreal CV (PDF)

title: Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
text:
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
MAEP Economics, McMaster University
I am studying how policy-imposed frictions and external shocks propagate through interconnected production systems. My work focuses on identifying when trade restrictions, energy disruptions, and industrial policy interventions induce adaptive reallocation, and when they instead generate persistent vulnerabilities and systemic risk.
Using dynamic AGE models, I study how investment incentives, substitution elasticities, and network structure shape aggregate resilience. My research is motivated by questions central to economic security, including supply-chain robustness, energy dependence, and exposure to geopolitical shocks.
My work is intended to support forward-looking risk assessment in environments characterized by strategic interaction, uncertainty, and incomplete information.
Research interests:
Macroeconomics · Production Networks · Energy Policy · Industrial Policy · Economic Security
Links
- Curriculum Vitae (PDF) - GitHub - Email: t.taylormcgreal@gmail.com

title: Industrial Policy Failure Modes: Where Incentives Go Off-Path
text:
Industrial policy often fails for operational reasons, not conceptual ones. Incentives that look coherent at launch drift once agencies, firms, and local governments optimize against different objectives.
Five repeat failure modes show up across sectors: - Subsidies tied to volume instead of productivity learning. - Weak performance gates that keep underperforming projects alive. - Fragmented governance that duplicates support across jurisdictions. - Political timing that front-loads announcements and back-loads execution. - No clear exit rules when programs stop producing strategic value.
A better design starts with milestones that are technical, auditable, and reversible. If the state cannot scale discipline with spending, industrial policy becomes transfer policy.

title: China’s EV Policy Playbook
text:
China’s EV rise wasn’t just market‑led. It was a tightly sequenced industrial strategy: stimulate demand early, subsidize supply, build charging infrastructure, then tighten performance standards as the market scales.
Key elements that mattered: - Early consumer subsidies to create a market floor. - Production support and R&D to move firms down cost curves. - Infrastructure build‑out to remove range anxiety. - Policy tightening to force quality upgrades and consolidation.
The lesson for Canada isn’t to copy the scale, but to copy the sequencing and discipline—especially the transition from broad support to performance‑based support.

title: Strategic Frictions and Systemic Risk
text: Policy frictions are rarely isolated. In tightly coupled economies, small distortions can propagate through production networks, magnify uncertainty, and alter the strategic calculus of states and firms. My interest is in identifying which nodes and linkages act as accelerants, and where targeted intervention can dampen systemic risk without imposing persistent misallocation.

title: EV Industrial Policy For Canada
text:
Canada assembles vehicles but captures too little of the IP and supply‑chain value. A serious EV strategy would aim at capability: batteries, power electronics, software, and testing standards—plus the supply chain for critical minerals.
A realistic policy mix: - Time‑limited protective space for domestic entrants. - R&D funding tied to measurable milestones. - National charging infrastructure as a demand catalyst. - Federal‑provincial coordination to prevent fragmented incentives.
The goal isn’t autarky. It’s a domestic core strong enough to compete and retain spillovers.

title: How Input-Output Centrality Predicts Shock Propagation
text:
Sector size is a weak proxy for systemic risk. In production networks, shock intensity depends on centrality: how many sectors depend on an input, how substitutable it is, and how quickly firms can re-route demand.
Three centrality features are consistently useful: - Upstream dependency density. - Low-substitution bottleneck inputs. - High pass-through into downstream cost structures.
This is why small sectors can generate large aggregate effects. A central node with low substitution can transmit a local disruption into economy-wide productivity and price pressure.

title: Early-Warning Indicators for Economic Coercion
text:
Economic coercion rarely starts with formal sanctions. It usually appears first as coordinated frictions in trade finance, customs timing, licensing, procurement, and standards enforcement.
A usable early-warning dashboard should track: - Sudden concentration shifts in critical import categories. - Unexplained inspection delays in politically sensitive sectors. - Credit tightening for firms linked to strategic supply chains. - Administrative rule changes that are neutral in text but selective in effect. - Pricing behavior that diverges from fundamentals in key intermediates.
No single indicator is decisive. The signal is in cross-market correlation and sequencing. The objective is to identify a coercion pathway early enough to reallocate exposure.

title: Stranded Barrels And A Shrinking Oil Market
text:
A permanent demand decline changes oil economics at the balance‑sheet level. Firms that collateralize debt against reserves face liquidity stress as prices and expected recoverable value fall—turning “proven” barrels into stranded assets.
At the same time, petro‑states may respond strategically by consolidating supply in a smaller market, moving toward oligopoly behavior. That creates a bifurcation: highly leveraged private producers exit while state producers gain market power.
The policy risk is double‑sided: financial instability in oil‑heavy regions and increased geopolitical leverage for the lowest‑cost producers.

title: The NDP’s Identity Problem
text:
The NDP’s challenge is less about ideology and more about coherence: the party’s wins in government have been incremental, while the public expects scale. That mismatch erodes perceived effectiveness.
Digital presence compounds the problem. In a politics shaped by short‑form media, a policy‑heavy communication style loses attention to simpler, more emotionally legible narratives.
If the NDP wants to regain ground, it needs tighter message discipline and a clearer story about immediate, tangible benefits—not just long‑run justice arguments.

title: Research
text:
I develop and solve static and dynamic general equilibrium models to study how policy constraints and external shocks affect investment, production, and reallocation in networked economies. My work emphasizes identifying structural conditions under which localized disruptions propagate into economy-wide vulnerabilities.
These tools are applied to questions in energy and climate policy, trade and industrial policy, and economic security, with a focus on mechanisms relevant for early-warning analysis and resilience assessment.

title: Research
text:
Working Papers

Optimal Carbon Taxation in a Dynamic General Equilibrium Economy
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
I develop and solve a dynamic general equilibrium model with capital accumulation and heterogeneous energy technologies to characterize the welfare-maximizing carbon tax path. The model highlights how investment responses and energy substitution jointly shape optimal policy and transition dynamics.

Paper
Code & replication materials (GitHub)

title: Research
text:
Work in Process

Policy Constraints, Production Networks, and Endogenous Investment
This project studies how trade restrictions, policy uncertainty, and input constraints propagate through production networks and alter firms’ incentives to invest in capacity, sourcing flexibility, and technology adoption. I characterize when constraints induce adaptive reorganization versus persistent fragility, with implications for supply-chain security, energy dependence, and exposure to geopolitical shocks.
The framework is designed to identify leverage points and bottlenecks that are not visible in partial-equilibrium or sector-isolated analyses.



Neural Networks in Strategic Environments
I developed a convolutional neural network to study the limits of pure function approximation in high-dimensional strategic settings. Using chess as a controlled environment, the model maps raw board states to position evaluations without search, rollout, or lookahead.
The project examines when pattern recognition succeeds in adversarial environments and when it fails due to strategic nonlocality, path dependence, and regime shifts. Results highlight systematic failure modes of static predictors when incentives, constraints, or opponent responses change—providing insight into the limits of reduced-form prediction in strategic economic and policy contexts.

title: Notes
text:
Short technical notes on models, data sources, and methods.
Updated intermittently.

title: Defection And Cooperation In Repeated Games
text:
I simulated a modified Prisoner’s Dilemma with common strategies (Tit‑for‑Tat, Grudger, Pavlov, Always Defect, etc.) to see which behaviors dominate in mixed environments.
The takeaway is not “always cooperate” or “always defect.” The best performers balance adaptability with deterrence. Highly forgiving strategies get exploited; rigid ones spiral into mutual punishment. The stable middle ground looks like conditional reciprocity with limited patience.
That logic maps to real negotiations: durable cooperation requires credible retaliation and the ability to return to cooperation.

title: Canada As An Airport Lounge
text:
Canada has produced world‑class ideas and institutions, yet often behaves like a polished transit hub rather than a destination. Capital, talent, and IP pass through; fewer companies scale at home. That gap matters when supply chains, climate policy, and security shocks demand domestic capacity.
The fix isn’t nostalgia. It’s a strategy: scale R&D into homegrown firms, align finance with industrial outcomes, and lower internal frictions so the national market actually functions like one. Pair that with disciplined resource development and clear rules around strategic ownership.
The point is not to abandon values but to operationalize them. Canada’s advantage is still real; it just needs a plan that keeps value creation inside the country.

title: Canada’s Bedrock Opportunity
text:
Canada’s resource base positions it as a pivotal supplier in a shifting energy and minerals landscape. But without export diversification and infrastructure, that advantage gets discounted in global markets.
Two constraints dominate: access to tidewater (pipelines, LNG terminals, ports) and policy coherence across provinces and the federal government. Without those, Canada stays a price taker—even with world‑class reserves.
A credible strategy pairs infrastructure build‑out with clean‑tech investment (e.g., CCS, grid upgrades) to keep exports competitive as the global energy mix shifts.

title: State Capacity and Policy Execution in Strategic Sectors
text:
Ambitious strategy fails when execution institutions are thin. In strategic sectors, policy success depends on whether the state can evaluate projects, enforce milestones, and update programs as conditions change.
Execution capacity has three practical components: - Technical procurement and evaluation capability. - Coordinated authority across ministries and levels of government. - Feedback systems that terminate weak projects and scale strong ones.
State capacity is not an abstract governance metric. It is the binding constraint on whether strategic policy produces capability or just announcements.

title: Do Big Rallies Predict Big Wins?
text:
Rallies are one of the most visible campaign tools, but the causal link to outcomes is unclear. A clean test needs timing, media coverage, and baseline partisanship controls.
The design I sketch is simple: regress vote share on rally attendance, with time‑to‑election weights, media amplification proxies, and demographic controls. A second layer tests “force projection” by seeing whether one party’s rallies reduce the opponent’s presence.
If the signal is real, rallies are more than optics; if not, they’re mostly narrative management. Either way, the method separates spectacle from effect.

title: Oil, Networks, And Canada’s TFP Slowdown
text:
Canada’s post‑2001 productivity slowdown looks different once you neutralize oil‑sector shocks without removing oil from the production network. I call this ON‑TFP: hold oil productivity and prices at 2001 levels, but keep its input linkages.
Using the Baqaee‑Farhi framework, the result is clear: aggregate TFP largely recovers once oil’s negative productivity shock is removed. The drag wasn’t a generalized innovation failure—it was network propagation from a central sector.
The implication is policy‑relevant: allocation and input‑cost spillovers can dominate national productivity trends, even when the shocked sector is small by value‑added.

title: When Reshoring Helps and When It Raises Systemic Cost
text:
Reshoring is not a universal resilience strategy. It works when foreign concentration risk is high, domestic scale economies are reachable, and substitution failures create strategic exposure.
It underperforms when: - Domestic production remains structurally higher cost with no learning curve. - Inputs still rely on concentrated upstream imports. - Policy support protects incumbents without productivity gains.
The relevant question is not “home versus foreign.” It is whether a supply configuration improves reliability per unit cost over the full risk cycle.

title: TADHG TAYLOR-MCGREAL
text:
Editing Guide
Quick edits 1. Homepage text: index.qmd 2. Research page: research.qmd 3. CV page: cv.qmd 4. Teaching page: teaching.qmd 5. Code & Data: code.qmd 6. Blog landing: blog.qmd 7. Hidden policy page: policy-applications.qmd 8. Styling: styles.css
Add a working paper (paste into research.qmd)
### Title of Paper  
**Your Name**

Short 2–3 sentence description.

- [Paper (PDF)](assets/papers/your_file.pdf)
- Code & replication materials (GitHub)
- Slides (coming soon)
Add a blog post 1. Copy posts/_template.qmd to a new file in posts/. 2. Name it like YYYY-MM-DD-short-title.qmd. 3. Fill in the title, date, description, and body.
Publish changes 1. quarto render 2. git add docs 3. git commit -m "Update site" 4. git push
